clinical_study.brief_title: Relationship Between Hemodynamic Change and Fluid Removed During Hemodialysis
clinical_study.official_title: Relationship Between Hemodynamic Change and Fluid Removed During Hemodialysis Measured by Non-invasive Monitor

brief_summary.textblock: Relationship between hemodynamic change and fluid removed during hemodialysis measured by non-invasive monitor

detailed_description.textblock: By applying non-invasive hemodynamic monitors (ex. ClearSight, I-COM), the trends of mean arterial pressure (MAP), stroke volume (SV), cardiac index (CI) and calculated systemic vascular resistance (SVR) were collected along with volume removal by hemodialysis on ESRD patients. All data were compared and analyzed to detect the sequential body volume status as well as the autonomic responses during hemodialysis.

primary_outcome.description: the fluid volume removed from hemodialysis (mL/hour),

primary_outcome.measure: changes of mean arterial pressure along with hemodialysis
primary_outcome.description: record of mean arterial pressure (mmHg) per 30 minutes

primary_outcome.measure: changes of heart rate along with hemodialysis
primary_outcome.description: record of heart rate (beats/ minute) per 30 minutes

primary_outcome.measure: changes of stroke volume along with hemodialysis
primary_outcome.description: record of stroke volume (SV, (mL/ beat)per 30 minutes

primary_outcome.measure: changes of cardiac output along with hemodialysis
primary_outcome.description: record of cardiac output ( liter/ minute)per 30 minutes

arm_group.description: record and observe the data including SVI, CI, SVR with clearSight during hemodialysis

intervention.description: MAP, HR, CO, SVI, from Non-invasive hemodynamic monitor

study_pop.textblock: end-stage renal disease patients who were under regular hemodialysis

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria:
1. Patients who were schedured with regular hemodialysis for end-stage renal disease.
Exclusion criteria:
1. Emergent hemodialysis
2. Medical conditions with poor peripheral circulation such as Raynaud's disease or PAOD
3. Skin defects or wounds over area to be applied for measurement (Wrist and fingers)
